subject: [LH] Re: Love-Hounds Digest, Vol 52, Issue 6
body:
Y'all are effing hilarious!!!!

> Message: 3
> Date: Sat, 12 May 2007 00:35:53 -0500 (CDT)
> From: ianm@brick.net
> Subject: Re: [LH] Kate Bush -- Bad Neighbor! (more details)
> To: love-hounds@gaffa.org
> Message-ID: <3041.66.167.102.28.1178948153.squirrel@66.167.102.28>
> Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
>
> Dear Donny,
>
> I don't normally get drawn into these kinds of things, but for the sake of
> argument, you should probably hear these things.  Let's address your
> cookie-cutter "talking points," one by one.
>
> 1) You stated "I will never agree that carbon dioxide is pollution. In
> fact, without carbon dioxide, there's no photosynthesis and we all die."
> Of course, we all need copper in our bodies, or we would die.  However,
> too much copper will kill you.  Too much copper in the soil, trouble  We
> all need water in our bodies, or we would die.  However, too much water
> can kill you (water intoxication, check it out, or, hey, drowning).
> There's all kinds of things that are necessary in the proper balance, or
> terrible things result.  Too much of a good thing.  Hell, too much
> nitrogen wouldn't be good, and all of the protein in your body contains
> it.
>
> Of course, you already know that.  You're just using a bad analogy to
> support your argument.  If you wish to be intellectually honest, you may
> NEVER use that as a talking point, ever again, in any discussion, with
> anyone.
>
> 2) Global Cooling - Your statement was that "not a single scientist" was
> able to answer "Why did we have global cooling through the 1950s, 1960s
> and half of the 1970s?"  This is correct, in so far as a single scientist
> did not answer it.  More accurately, several scientists HAVE answered it.
>
> Let's have a quick tour of global cooling, shall we?  Global cooling, that
> brief cooldown around the 70's, back when we first started keeping really
> accurate data, was mostly due to the release of sulfate aerosols, which we
> have since ceased to do.  Sulfate aerosols have a large cooling effect.
> Since you like Wikipedia, check out
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attribution_of_recent_climate_change#Attribution_of_20th_century_climate_change.
>  Notice the light purple line in the chart, for the negative contribution
> of sulfate emissions.  You can see that the modeled temperatures follow
> the observed ones pretty well - that means that our science is getting
> more accurate.  The Global Cooling article on Wikipedia has a heck of a
> lot of info.  Check it out.
>
> You have now been informed on this topic, since your stance was that no
> scientist has ever answered it before.  They have.  If you wish to be
> intellectually honest, you may NEVER use that as a talking point, ever
> again, in any discussion, with anyone.
>
> 3 & 4) Optimum recommendations of temperature and carbon dioxide levels.
> Aside from medical science, scientists do not make "optimum
> recommendations."  They made predictions based on past data and explain
> observations.  The question might be better phrased as "optimum
> recommendations in order to do ... what?"  Well, if you want a lot of
> storms and some new coastlines, yeah, let's let it cook for a while
> longer.  The dinosaurs liked it nice and toasty, too.  We can look at
> historical data, obtained from as many sources as we can get, and make
> some fairly educated calculations.  Clearly, nobody wants to jack up the
> surface albedo so high that we get another little ice age.
>
> Science isn't going to answer the question for you, "How hot do you like
> your room?"  You'll have to figure that out for yourself, based on the
> consequences.  Scientists haven't determined a favorite color, either.
>
> It boils down to something very simple ... we have precisely one (1)
> planet upon which we may experiment.  We don't get another one if we screw
> it up (unless you believe in The Rapture).  This leads me, personally, to
> err on the side of caution.  We are already powerful enough to make
> species go extinct, make new species, divert entire rivers for our
> transportation needs, poison areas and make them uninhabitable, turn
> deserts into oases, and so forth.  We have those abilities.  It's not a
> stretch to think we could affect the atmosphere, too.
>
> Now, you probably will keep using that global cooling thing, and the bit
> about needing carbon dioxide, but, since I have called you on it, just
> remember that you now know better, every time you use it.
>
> Of course, I have a sneaking suspicion that, as someone from
> jesusanswers.com, you figure that the Second Coming will just take care of
> any messes people make.
>
> > In article <3YidnXU4GN0x7dnbnZ2dnUVZ_h2pnZ2d@giganews.com>,
> >  yellowmatter@gmail.com (yellowmattercustard) wrote:
> >
> >> Donny Bravo wrote:
> >>
> >> > Global Warming is not about pollution. It's about carbon
> >> > dioxide...supposedly.
> >> >
> >> > I will never agree that carbon dioxide is pollution. In fact, without
> >> > carbon dioxide, there's no photosynthesis and we all die.
> >>
> >> Fucking hopeless.
> >>
> >> It's like talking to a brick wall.
> >
> > A brick wall with the truth written on it.
> >
> > But, hey, if "fucking hopeless" is the best you can come up with to
> > answer my questions, you pretty much prove my point.
> >
> > Thanks!
> >
> > - Donny
> >
> >
